title: How to Season Scrambled Eggs

methods.name: Seasoning Eggs with Herbs and Spices

steps.headline: Add a dash of salt and pepper to eggs after cooking them.
steps.description: Salt and pepper are classic, simple seasonings for scrambled eggs. If you don't want to overpower the eggs with complex flavors, then this is a great option! Add a few dashes of salt and pepper to cooked eggs to adjust the flavor. Be sure to taste the eggs after adding a few dashes of salt and pepper! It is easy to over season them if you are not careful.

steps.headline: Use a spice or spice blend to get a specific flavor profile.
steps.description:
Choose individual spices to add to your eggs, or opt for a spice blend to achieve the flavors you want. Add a few dashes of the spices of your choice to raw eggs and whisk them into the eggs before you cook them. Some good options include:
Cumin
Chili powder
Paprika
Cayenne pepper (to make extra spicy eggs)
Cajun blend

steps.headline: Add a pinch of fresh or dried herbs.
steps.description:
If you prefer the flavors of herbs, try adding a pinch of some freshly cut herbs or a few dashes of dried herbs. Whisk the herbs into the raw eggs before you cook them. Some good options include:
Basil
Oregano
Thyme
Chives
Rosemary
Sage
Pair egg seasonings with other complementary ingredients: 
Add a few dashes of cumin and chili powder, plus 1 dash of cayenne pepper for spicy southwest eggs. Create Italian eggs with a combo of fresh or dried basil, oregano, and rosemary. You can also add in 1 medium chopped tomato and 1 oz (28 g) of parmesan.Make savory herb eggs with a mixture of garlic, thyme, sage, and rosemary!

steps.headline: Whip 1  fl oz (30 mL) of whole milk into the raw eggs.
steps.description: Whole milk can help to add richness to your eggs and it will also make them fluffier. Whisk the milk into the raw eggs before you cook them. Use heavy cream or half and half for even richer eggs, or opt for low-fat milk or water if you just want to improve the texture of the eggs by making them fluffier. Add 1  fl oz (30 mL) of milk for every 3 eggs.

steps.headline: Sprinkle 1 oz (28 g) of shredded or crumbled cheese over cooked eggs.
steps.description:
If you like the flavor of cheese, then add some to your eggs after they finish cooking. Choose your favorite type of cheese and shred or crumble it over the eggs after you finish cooking them. Turn off the heat and let the eggs sit in the pan for moment so the cheese will melt. This will add a nice, savory complement to your eggs. Some good options include:
Feta cheese
Parmesan
Cheddar (mild or sharp)
Swiss
Pepperjack

steps.headline: Melt 2 oz (57 g) of cream cheese into the eggs.
steps.description: If you want your eggs to have a creamy, tangy element, then add about 2 oz (57 g) of cream cheese to the pan about 1 to 2 minutes before the eggs are finished cooking. Then, stir the eggs around in the pan to distribute the cream cheese and allow it to melt in with the eggs. Use 2 oz (57 g) of cream cheese for every 3 eggs.

steps.headline: Sauté mushrooms, onions, and garlic before scrambling eggs in the pan.
steps.description: To add savory flavors to your eggs with veggies, sauté 4 oz (110 g) of chopped mushrooms, 2 oz (57 g) of chopped onions, and 2 cloves of minced garlic in 0.5  fl oz (15 mL) of butter or oil on medium-high heat for about 5 minutes. Then, pour the raw eggs into the pan and scramble the eggs as usual. Remember that you can use any combination of veggies (and fruits) that you like to season your eggs. Try subbing 4 oz (110 g) of chopped apples for the mushrooms and garlic for a sweet take on scrambled eggs.

steps.headline: Chop up some deli meat or cooked bacon and add it to the eggs.
steps.description: Meat can be a flavorful addition to scrambled eggs, too. You can add just about any type of meat you like to your scrambled eggs. Just make sure to cook raw meats separately to ensure that they are cooked thoroughly. Fry up 2 slices of bacon and crumble them into your cooked eggs. Cook 2 links of breakfast sausage, cut them into bite sized pieces, and mix them into cooked eggs. Chop up a few slices of deli ham, turkey, or roast beef and stir them into your scrambled eggs during the last 1 to 2 minutes of cooking.

steps.headline: Add a handful of fresh greens to the pan while you cook the eggs.
steps.description:
Fresh greens are often bursting with flavor, which can be a refreshing addition to scrambled eggs. Opt for your favorite type of greens and add them to the pan during the last 1 to 2 minutes of cooking the eggs to wilt the greens slightly. Try fresh baby spinach for a mild flavor and soft texture. Opt for kale for bold greens with a crunchy texture. Try beet greens or Swiss chard for a touch of bitter flavor and a hearty bite. Buy convenience items to add to your scrambled eggs: 
Use pre-cut fresh or frozen veggies to add flavor to your eggs! Cook frozen veggies before adding them to your eggs. Keep a bag of pre-shredded or crumbled cheese on hand. This will make it easy to quickly add a cheese topping to cooked eggs. Get pre-cooked bacon or sausage instead of cooking raw meat. Look for the frozen kind that you can pop in the microwave to re-heat.

steps.headline: Enjoy a few dashes of hot sauce on your eggs.
steps.description: Adding a few dashes of hot sauce to your eggs is an easy way to take them from bland to bursting with flavor! Choose your favorite hot sauce and add just a few dashes to start. Taste the eggs to see if you want to add any more. Be cautious when adding hot sauce, especially if it is extra hot! Hot sauce usually ranges from mild to hot, so you may only need a few drops.

steps.headline: Pour salsa over your eggs.
steps.description: Salsa is a fantastic compliment to cooked eggs! This works especially well if you have seasoned your eggs with cheddar cheese and a Cajun spice blend, but you can add salsa to plain eggs, too. Pour about 2  fl oz (59 mL) of salsa over cooked eggs to give them a spicy, bold flavor. Use any type of salsa you like, such as green, roasted tomato, or pineapple salsa. Complement the salsa with fresh avocado slices, a couple of spoonfuls of sour cream, or a sprinkle of fresh chopped cilantro.

steps.headline: Dip your cooked eggs in ketchup, barbeque sauce, or steak sauce.
steps.description: Traditional American condiments can be great complements to plain or seasoned cooked eggs! Experiment with a few to see what you like. You may discover that you love the combination of eggs and ketchup or another type of condiment. Try some less conventional options as well.

steps.headline: Add a few splashes of soy or teriyaki sauce to cooked eggs.
steps.description:
If you enjoy the flavors of Asian cuisine, try seasoning your eggs with your favorite Asian condiment. Try soy sauce if you want your eggs to be just a touch salty, or add teriyaki sauce for something a bit more flavorful. You could even try sweet and sour sauce, duck sauce, or sweet chili pepper sauce for something bolder. Only add a little sauce to flavor the eggs if you pour it right on top of them. You can always add more! Add Condiments to Eggs:
While they are still cooking. Try this option for salsa, soy sauce, and barbeque sauce. After they are finished cooking if you want all over flavor. As a dip for your eggs. Make up a few sauce dishes and dip each bite of eggs into a different sauce!
